issues.description: Inconsistent capitalization of the table name 'Gemeinde' across artifacts: the problem statement refers to the table as 'Gemeinde' (capitalized as a German noun), while the solution files are inconsistent â€” most solution queries use 'Gemeinde' but aufgabe04.sql uses 'gemeinde' (lowercase). On case-sensitive SQL systems this mismatch can cause errors and will confuse students about the correct identifier to use.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the table identifier consistent across all artifacts. Update solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql to use the same capitalization as the other files and the problem statement (e.g. FROM Gemeinde). Alternatively, add a note in the problem statement that identifiers are case-insensitive in the exercise environment if that is guaranteed. Consistent naming prevents confusing errors on case-sensitive DBs.

issues.description: The same conceptual entity (the municipality table 'Gemeinde') is referenced with inconsistent identifier casing across artifacts: the problem statement and several solution files use 'Gemeinde' (capital G), while solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql uses 'gemeinde' (lowercase). This casing difference can create unnecessary mapping confusion for students trying to relate the problem text to the provided solution SQL, especially because other solution files (e.g. aufgabe02.sql, aufgabe05.sql) use the capitalized form.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a consistent table identifier across all artifacts. Either rename 'gemeinde' in solution_repository/aufgabe04.sql to 'Gemeinde' (FROM gemeinde -> FROM Gemeinde) to match the problem statement and other solution files, or standardize all references to lowercase 'gemeinde' throughout the solution files and documentation. Note: while many SQL engines are case-insensitive for identifiers, using a single consistent form avoids cognitive mapping load for students.
